Schistocytes are noted on peripheral blood smear.
The patient is able to provide a urine sample. Urinalysis reveals a specific gravity of 1.020 (reference range, 1.001–1.035), a positive finding for blood, and 2+ protein. Urine osmolality is 400 mOsm/kg, and the fractional excretion of sodium is <1%.
Stool studies are positive for enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli.
What is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

choices.text: Infuse 5% dextrose in 0.45% normal saline and potassium chloride 20 mEq/liter at maintenance rate
Administer a 10- to 20-mL/kg bolus of 0.9% saline
Infuse 10% dextrose in water 5 mL/kg at maintenance rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient were anuric, then a trial of furosemide may be advised before the administration of any fluid, in order to determine if there is still some urine output.

B) INCORRECT:

The use of maintenance fluids is not appropriate, as this option assumes normal volume status and normal kidney function. In addition, potassium should not be added to the fluids for the first 24 to 48 hours because of the risk for hyperkalemia in this patient with oliguria.

C) INCORRECT:

If the patient were anuric, then a trial of furosemide may be advised before the administration of any fluid, in order to determine if there is still some urine output.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of acute intrinsic kidney injury secondary to hemolytic uremic syndrome, but the persistent diarrhea has led to evidence of volume depletion. Resuscitation with isotonic saline is appropriate even though there is evidence of intrinsic renal disease.

Acute kidney injury is defined as a sudden decline in glomerular filtration rate, typically with laboratory evidence of an increase in serum creatinine. The causes of acute kidney injury can be divided into three categories:

• Prerenal injury reflects a functional decrease in perfusion of the kidney, but the renal parenchyma is intact. This can occur from volume depletion (as from gastrointestinal losses, blood loss, or third spacing) or effective volume depletion (as in congestive heart failure or cirrhosis). Restoration of perfusion will promptly improve kidney function.
• Intrinsic or parenchymal renal injury can result from damage to the glomeruli, tubules, or interstitium. Tubular damage can occur from ischemic damage to the kidney (as with prerenal injury but without restoration of perfusion) or from toxins.
• Postrenal injury results from obstruction to urinary flow. Examples include bladder outlet obstruction or obstruction of one or both ureters.

Prerenal injury and ischemic damage to the tubules (also called acute tubular necrosis) may occur in the same clinical circumstances. Restoration of perfusion with intravenous fluids can distinguish between the two conditions because prerenal injury will improve rapidly. However, in some cases, significant intravenous fluid resuscitation is best avoided, and additional data can be used to determine which of the two conditions is more likely. See “Determination of the likely mechanism of acute kidney injury” table.

Acute kidney injury is managed with supportive care, including fluids, nutrition, and monitoring of electrolytes and blood pressure. If there is evidence of intravascular volume depletion, then this should be treated even if there is also evidence of intrinsic renal disease. After restoration of intravascular volume, the patient’s fluid status and electrolyte levels should be maintained by judiciously monitoring the patient’s weight, intake, and output (including renal, extrarenal, and insensible losses).

This patient has evidence of intravascular volume depletion (tachycardia, dry mucous membranes and delayed capillary refill as well as weight loss) and should therefore be resuscitated with isotonic fluids, such as normal saline or lactated Ringer solution. Because patients with acute glomerular injury may have elevated blood pressure, this may be a less reliable sign of intravascular volume depletion. Also, in patients with hemolysis, rehydration is likely to result in demonstration of worse underlying anemia than previously recognized. If the patient were anuric, then a trial of furosemide may be advised before the administration of any fluid, in order to determine if there is still some urine output. If there is no urine output, fluids should be administered only to restore effective circulating volume and then should be restricted to insensible output to avoid fluid overload.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial fluids for a patient with volume depletion and acute intrinsic renal injury are isotonic fluids administered at 10 to 20 mL/kg.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has no evidence of hypoglycemia and would not benefit from a dextrose-only bolus.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe muscle soreness, nausea, and darkened urine for 2 days. The patient is on the college track team and has been training intensively for an upcoming event. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. There is diffuse muscle tenderness over the arms, legs, and back. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Creatine kinase
22,000 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase
380 U/L


Urine



 Blood
3+


 Protein
1+


 RBC
negative


This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common complication of rhabdomyolysis and crush syndrome. The excessive muscle breakdown results in increased free myoglobin and subsequent myoglobinuria (darkened urine without detectable RBCs). Pigments of heme-containing proteins, e.g., myoglobin or hemoglobin can harm the kidney tubules (= pigment nephropathy), causing acute tubular necrosis and subsequent AKI. Volume depletion secondary to third-spacing of fluid into the injured muscles leads to decreased renal perfusion and may thus further impair kidney function.

Patients with rhabdomyolysis require careful resuscitation with IV fluids and close monitoring of their urine output and electrolytes. Hemodialysis may be indicated in cases of severe AKI. Patients should also be monitored for compartment syndrome, as overly rapid fluid resuscitation can lead to increasing edema of the injured muscle and its adjacent compartment, potentially threatening its perfusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Seizures can be caused by numerous factors, including metabolic and electrolyte abnormalities. While severe rhabdomyolysis manifests with hyperkalemia and lactic acidosis, seizures are not a common complication. Seizures, especially tonic-clonic ones, can cause (rather than result from) rhabdomyolysis secondary to excessive muscle contractions.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome is a potentially limb-threatening surgical emergency that may cause or occur secondary to rhabdomyolysis. However, compartment syndrome secondary to rhabdomyolysis typically develops after fluid resuscitation, which this patient has not yet received. Another complication is more likely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Acid-base disturbances are common in patients with rhabdomyolysis. Edema-associated muscle ischemia and excess muscle breakdown result in the production and/or release of organic acids, such as lactic acid or uric acid, which causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis rather than alkalosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia, especially intravascular hemolytic anemia, may manifest with darkened urine as a result of the excess free hemoglobin circulating in the bloodstream. Free hemoglobin may accumulate during the breakdown and destruction of erythrocytes. This patient, however, most likely suffers from rhabdomyolysis, which does not cause hemolytic anemia.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with diffuse muscle tenderness, highly elevated creatine kinase, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase is suggestive of muscle injury. These features together with darkened urine in the absence of RBCs on urinalysis indicate rhabdomyolysis, most likely due to overexertion as a result of the intensive training.

questions.text:
Nine days after being treated for a perforated gastric ulcer and sepsis, a 78-year-old woman develops decreased urinary output and malaise. She required emergency laparotomy and was subsequently treated in the intensive care unit for sepsis. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission, her medications were insulin, ramipril, and ibuprofen. The patient was treated with ceftazidime and gentamicin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a healing surgical incision in the upper abdomen. Serum studies show:


Na+

137 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


K+

5.1 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


Creatinine
4.2 mg/dL


Fractional excretion of sodium is 2.1%. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fatty casts on urine microscopy are a characteristic finding in nephrotic syndrome. This manifests in massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/24 h), edema, and compensatory hyperlipidemia, which is not consistent with this patient's findings.

B) CORRECT:

Muddy brown casts are specific to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), the most common cause of intrinsic AKI. This patient has multiple risk factors for kidney injury, including advanced age, history of sepsis, diabetes mellitus, and long use of nephrotoxic agents (e.g., ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs). This woman's ATN is most likely due to her recent treatment with gentamicin, which is a nephrotoxic aminoglycoside antibiotic.

See “Urinary casts” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine sediment (high magnification)

Renal tubular epithelial cell casts (a) and muddy brown casts (b) were identified in this urine sample.

Both findings indicate damage of the kidneys, likely due to acute tubular necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

RBC casts in urinary sediment indicate glomerulonephritis (GN) and are caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. GN results in red or cola-colored urine, proteinuria (< 3.5 g/24 h), and edema, which is not consistent with this patient's findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyaline casts are the most commonly observed casts in urine sediment analysis. Their presence is nonspecific. They are commonly seen in healthy individuals who have recently exercised vigorously or been dehydrated. This patient presents with signs of acute kidney injury, making a different type of cast more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Waxy casts are nonspecific findings that are most commonly found in chronic kidney disease because they can best form in low urine flow states. Waxy casts are observed only in longstanding nephrotic range proteinuria. This patient is very unlikely to have chronic nephrotic syndrome because she does not present with proteinuria and edema, and her symptoms of renal involvement began only 1 day ago.
questions.hint: Oliguria, hyperkalemia, elevated BUN and creatinine with a BUN:Cr ratio < 15:1, and a fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) > 2% are consistent with intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI).

questions.text: Ten days after being discharged from the hospital, a 42-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of reduced urine output for 3 days. Physical examination is normal. Serum creatinine concentration is 2.9 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows brownish granular casts and 2+ proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows patchy necrosis of the proximal convoluted tubule with sloughing of tubular cells into the lumen and preservation of tubular basement membranes. Administration of which of the following drugs during hospitalization is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor used in the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. In cases of renal hypoperfusion, such as intravascular volume depletion and bilateral renal artery stenosis, ACE inhibitors can cause decreased GFR, elevated creatinine, and oliguria, as in this patient. However, ACE inhibitors would not result in ATN or significant findings on renal biopsy, making captopril an unlikely cause of this patient's renal failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is a type of NSAID typically used in the management of pain, fever, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease prophylaxis. NSAIDs can cause allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN). AIN can manifest with oliguria and elevated creatinine, which are seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features of AIN, e.g., fever, rash, and eosinophiluria. Additionally, renal biopsy in AIN shows interstitial edema with mononuclear infiltrate. This is inconsistent with this patient's biopsy findings, making aspirin an unlikely cause of his renal failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral agent used to treat herpes simplex and varicella zoster infections. Acyclovir can cause crystal-induced acute kidney injury, which can manifest with elevated creatinine and proteinuria. However, in the case of crystal-induced nephropathy, crystals would be visible on urine microscopy rather than granular casts. Acyclovir is therefore an unlikely cause of this patient's renal failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) commonly used to treat peptic ulcer disease and dyspepsia. A rare side effect of PPI agents is allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN). AIN can manifest with oliguria and elevated creatinine, as in this patient. However, this patient lacks other classic features of AIN, e.g., fever, rash, and eosinophiluria. Additionally, renal biopsy in AIN shows interstitial edema with mononuclear infiltrate. This is inconsistent with this patient's biopsy findings, making omeprazole an unlikely cause of his renal failure.

E) CORRECT:

Aminoglycoside antibiotics such as gentamicin are one of the most common causes of toxic ATN, which is characterized by damage and possible consequent necrosis of the proximal convoluted tubules, as seen on this patient's biopsy findings. ATN manifests with oliguria, uremia, and muddy brown granular casts within the first two weeks of a kidney injury. Treatment includes discontinuation of nephrotoxic agents, supportive care, and dialysis if necessary.
questions.hint: Oliguria, elevated serum creatinine, granular muddy brown casts, proteinuria, and patchy necrosis of the proximal tubule indicate acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man is evaluated for altered mental status. He was admitted to a rehabilitation facility 2 weeks ago after undergoing right-hip replacement for a hip fracture. He has a history of hypertension treated with amlodipine and metoprolol and type 2 diabetes treated with insulin. His baseline creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg, and pulse is 80/min. He is disoriented to place and time. Clinically significant erythema and tenderness are evident at the incision site over the right hip. Laboratory testing yields the following results:


Hemoglobin
13.0 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,500/mm3



Sodium
138 mEq/L


Potassium
5.0 mEq/L


Blood urea nitrogen
35 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.1 mEq/L


The urine sodium level is increased. Urine microscopy shows granular casts. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of acute kidney injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urine microscopy is an important tool in evaluating acute kidney injury. The finding of granular casts and high urinary sodium in the setting of hypotension and infection (in this case, a postoperative wound infection) is highly suggestive of acute tubular necrosis.

Although this patient’s baseline serum creatinine level (1.2 mg/dL) was within the normal reference range, older individuals typically have reduced muscle mass and would be expected to have a serum creatinine level ≤1 mg/dL. Therefore, this patient may have had reduced renal function at baseline. He also has a history of hypertension that is treated with two agents. Relative hypotension caused by the systemic inflammatory response syndrome from infection can contribute to the propensity to renal ischemia.

Key learning point: A finding of granular casts and an increased sodium level in the urine is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Prerenal azotemia can also occur in the setting of hypotension and infection. When prerenal azotemia is the cause, the kidney retains the ability to conserve sodium. As a result, the urinary sodium is typically low, not high as in this case. Although the urine sediment in prerenal azotemia is usually bland, a few hyaline or fine granular casts are occasionally noted.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis, which can be associated with fever and altered renal function, is often accompanied by eosinophilia, pyuria, or white-cell casts. In this case, none of those features are present.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A nephropathy and infection-associated glomerulonephritis are glomerular diseases typically associated with a finding of red cells or red-cell casts on urine microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A nephropathy and infection-associated glomerulonephritis are glomerular diseases typically associated with a finding of red cells or red-cell casts on urine microscopy.

questions.text: An 83-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 2 days of fatigue, anorexia, and nausea. His medical history includes hypertension, for which he has been taking lisinopril and chlorthalidone. Eight days ago, he developed nasal congestion, sore throat, and low-grade fever. He had limited oral intake at the time, but his symptoms improved after treatment with naproxen. He has slightly elevated jugular venous pressure, fine bibasilar crackles in the lungs, and mild lower-leg edema. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a blood urea nitrogen level of 58 mg/dL, a serum creatinine level of 4.6 mg/dL (increased from his baseline level of 1.6 mg/dL), and a potassium level of 5.2 mEq/liter. A dipstick urinalysis shows 1+ protein. The urinary sediment shows 0 to 2 red cells per high-power field, 1 to 3 white cells per high-power field, and a few granular and hyaline casts. What is the most likely cause of this patient's abnormal laboratory results?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Many patients with IgA nephropathy present with one or recurrent episodes of visible hematuria within one or two days of an upper respiratory infection, while others are found to have microscopic hematuria and proteinuria. The disease is usually restricted to the kidney and is not typically associated with acute uremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is often preceded by an infection and is characterized by purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic-uremic syndrome is characterized by hemolytic anemia, acute kidney failure, and thrombocytopenia. It predominantly affects children, and most cases are preceded by an episode of diarrhea caused by Escherichia coli O157:H7.

D) CORRECT:

This patient had poor oral intake for several days while he had an upper respiratory tract infection. The hypovolemia induced by the poor oral intake, possibly with increased insensible fluid losses from a febrile illness, combined with treatment involving an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, a diuretic, and a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), likely led to acute kidney injury, which was confirmed by the elevated serum creatinine level. The patient’s current symptoms of nausea coincident with fatigue and anorexia are all likely due to uremia, most likely from medication-induced decreased glomerular perfusion.

Key learning point: In the setting of volume depletion and the use of agents that block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis, the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can precipitate acute kidney injury.

E) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs can cause interstitial nephritis, but the time course and clinical history in this case are more consistent with medication-induced decreased glomerular perfusion. When medications cause acute interstitial nephritis, the mean time from beginning the medication to the initial signs of renal dysfunction is 10 days, although it can be faster if the patient has taken the medication previously. Given that this patient’s serum creatinine level is >4 mg/dL, the onset of renal dysfunction would be expected to have occurred at least 4 days earlier. This time course makes interstitial nephritis much less likely. Interstitial nephritis can be accompanied by fever, rash, eosinophilia, pyuria, and even white-cell casts. The absence of these features does not exclude interstitial nephritis but also makes the diagnosis unlikely in light of the timing.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of reduced oral intake, generalized weakness, and minimal urine output. He has a history of congestive heart failure and type 2 diabetes. He reports no recent intravenous fluid therapy or changes to his medications. He has cool extremities. Physical examination reveals decreased skin turgor and an absent jugular venous pulse (see lab results).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
310 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Blood urea nitrogen
18 mmol/L
2.8 - 8.9 mmol/L


Urine




 Fractional excretion of sodium
0.8%
1 - 2%



Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Restrict fluid intake and monitor outputs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluid restriction is used in fluid overload, such as in congestive heart failure exacerbations. This patient, however, presents with signs of hypovolemia, including decreased skin turgor and low fractional excretion of sodium, indicating volume depletion rather than overload. Restricting fluids would worsen renal perfusion and kidney function.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated for suspected bacterial infections or sepsis. This patient, however, shows signs of dehydration, such as decreased skin turgor and cool extremities, and laboratory findings suggest prerenal azotemia. There is no evidence of infection or sepsis, such as fever or systemic inflammation.

C) CORRECT:

The patient presents with hypotension, tachycardia, cool extremities, decreased skin turgor, and an absent jugular venous pulse, indicating volume depletion. Laboratory findings show elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels, with a low fractional excretion of sodium (0.8%), consistent with prerenal azotemia due to reduced renal perfusion. Intravenous isotonic saline infusion is the appropriate initial management to restore intravascular volume, improve renal blood flow, and reverse the ischemic state causing the azotemia. This approach addresses the underlying hypovolemia, which leads to reduced glomerular filtration rate despite normal renal parenchyma.

Key learning point: In cases of hypovolemia with prerenal azotemia, careful intravenous saline infusion is indicated to restore intravascular volume and improve renal perfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics are used to manage fluid overload in congestive heart failure. However, this patient shows signs of hypovolemia, such as cool extremities, decreased skin turgor, and low fractional excretion of sodium. Administering loop diuretics would further decrease intravascular volume, worsening hypotension and renal hypoperfusion.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of profuse watery diarrhea, thirst, and lightheadedness. He has lost 3 kg since the onset of symptoms. He appears fatigued. Over the last 12 hours, his urine output has decreased to 250 mL. He has no flank tenderness, and renal ultrasound is normal (see lab results).


Heart rate
108/min


Blood pressure
90/58 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Bicarbonate
19 mmol/L
21 - 28 mmol/L


Potassium
3.4 mmol/L
3.5 - 5.1 mmol/L


Blood urea nitrogen
7.8 mmol/L
2.8 - 8.9 mmol/L



Which of the following best explains his decreased urine output?

choices.text: Reduced renal perfusion from volume depletion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrinsic tubular damage, such as acute tubular necrosis, results from sustained ischemia or nephrotoxin exposure, leading to cellular injury and granular casts. This patient's short history of diarrhea and volume depletion suggests reduced renal perfusion rather than direct tubular injury. The normal renal ultrasound and lab data do not indicate intrinsic tubular damage.

B) CORRECT:

Profuse watery diarrhea results in significant fluid loss, leading to decreased effective circulating volume and reduced renal perfusion. This reduction in intravascular volume decreases renal blood flow, lowering the glomerular filtration rate and urine output. The body compensates by activating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system to promote sodium and water reabsorption, maintaining blood pressure. The normal renal ultrasound excludes structural abnormalities, supporting a functional reduction in urine output due to volume depletion.

Key learning point: In cases of dehydration and mild metabolic acidosis, decreased urine output is a common clinical sign due to reduced renal perfusion and compensatory fluid conservation.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral ureteral obstruction reduces urine output by blocking urinary drainage, often causing flank pain and hydronephrosis. This patient lacks flank tenderness, and the normal renal ultrasound excludes hydronephrosis, making obstruction unlikely. The acute diarrhea and volume depletion suggest a non-obstructive cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is released in response to hypovolemia to conserve water, but the primary cause of decreased urine output here is reduced renal perfusion from volume depletion. Conditions with excessive ADH secretion, like the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, typically involve euvolemia and hyponatremia, not seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is scheduled for contrast-enhanced CT imaging of his abdomen. He has a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and stage 3 chronic kidney disease. He takes metformin and lisinopril daily. Evaluation shows serum creatinine of 160 µmol/L and estimated glomerular filtration rate of 42 mL/min/1.73 m². Electrolytes are within normal limits. He has no edema or signs of volume overload. He is scheduled for intravenous iodinated contrast administration and is concerned about potential kidney damage (see lab results).


Heart rate
78/min


Blood pressure
142/85 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
160 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Estimated glomerular filtration rate
42 mL/min/1.73 m²
90 - 120 mL/min/1.73 m²



Which of the following interventions is most effective in reducing the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate hemodialysis is not effective in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy. Renal injury from iodinated contrast occurs due to direct tubular toxicity and hemodynamic changes that happen immediately upon exposure. Hemodialysis initiated post-procedure does not prevent these effects and carries risks like hypotension, which can worsen renal injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is thought to reduce contrast-induced nephropathy due to its antioxidant properties. However, clinical evidence supporting its efficacy is inconsistent, with issues like limited bioavailability and first-pass metabolism reducing effective antioxidant levels in the kidneys. More robust interventions are available for preventing nephrotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous loop diuretics increase diuresis but can lead to volume depletion, reducing renal perfusion and exacerbating ischemic injury in chronic kidney disease. Enhanced urine output does not mitigate direct tubular toxicity or ischemic effects of contrast media, making this approach ineffective in reducing contrast-induced kidney injury.

D) CORRECT:

Intravenous 0.9% saline infusion is crucial in reducing the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, especially in patients with chronic kidney disease and diabetes mellitus. This intervention enhances renal perfusion and increases glomerular filtration rate by expanding intravascular volume. Improved renal blood flow facilitates the dilution and elimination of iodinated contrast, reducing nephrotoxic concentration in renal tubules. Additionally, adequate hydration mitigates renal vasoconstriction associated with contrast exposure, minimizing ischemic injury. Isotonic saline infusion is typically started before and continued after the procedure to maintain fluid balance and protect against acute kidney injury.

Key learning point: Adequate hydration with intravenous 0.9% sodium chloride pre- and post-procedure is the most effective strategy to reduce the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with acute kidney injury has persistent hyperkalemia (7.0 mEq/L) and QRS widening despite medical therapy. Which next step is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient has severe hyperkalemia with a potassium level of 7.0 mEq/L and QRS widening, indicating a high risk of cardiac conduction disturbances. Hemodialysis is the definitive treatment to rapidly remove excess potassium, especially in acute kidney injury where renal clearance is impaired. While medical therapies can temporarily shift potassium intracellularly, persistent ECG changes necessitate immediate dialytic intervention to prevent arrhythmias and manage uremic complications.

Key learning point: Urgent hemodialysis in acute kidney injury is indicated for life-threatening complications such as refractory hyperkalemia and anuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Nebulized beta₂ agonists, like albuterol, shift potassium into cells, modestly reducing serum levels. However, in severe hyperkalemia with QRS widening, this effect is insufficiently rapid or robust to mitigate cardiac risk. A more definitive intervention is needed to rapidly lower potassium and stabilize the myocardium.

C) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics promote urinary potassium excretion, but their effectiveness depends on adequate renal function. In acute kidney injury, reduced glomerular filtration limits their utility. The presence of QRS widening indicates severe hyperkalemia requiring rapid potassium removal, which diuretics cannot achieve in this context.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous insulin shifts potassium into cells, temporarily lowering serum levels. However, in the presence of persistent hyperkalemia and QRS widening, the current insulin dose is likely maximized, or the potassium burden is too high. Increasing insulin risks hypoglycemia and does not remove potassium from the body, which is crucial in acute kidney injury with cardiotoxicity.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with two days of confusion and poor oral intake. He has reduced skin turgor (see lab results).


Heart rate
112/min


Blood pressure
88/60 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Blood urea nitrogen
20 mmol/L
2.8 - 8.9 mmol/L


Creatinine
203 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which of the following best explains the increased BUN/Cr ratio in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased creatinine excretion from tubular damage
Increased urea reabsorption due to decreased renal perfusion
Obstruction of the urinary tract elevating systemic creatinine
Excessive urea production from high protein catabolism

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tubular damage, as in acute tubular necrosis, reduces creatinine clearance but also limits urea reabsorption, keeping the BUN/creatinine ratio closer to normal. The patient's signs of volume depletion suggest prerenal azotemia, where increased urea reabsorption elevates the BUN/creatinine ratio.

B) CORRECT:

In prerenal acute kidney injury, decreased renal perfusion triggers compensatory mechanisms to conserve intravascular volume. This leads to increased reabsorption of water and solutes, including urea, in the proximal tubule. Urea is reabsorbed with water, unlike creatinine, resulting in a disproportionate rise in blood urea nitrogen (BUN) compared to creatinine. This process explains the elevated BUN/creatinine ratio in hypovolemic conditions, as seen in this patient with dehydration and hypotension.

Key learning point: In prerenal acute kidney injury due to hypovolemia, the blood urea nitrogen/creatinine ratio is typically elevated (> 20) due to increased reabsorption of urea.

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract obstruction elevates creatinine due to impaired excretion but does not significantly increase the BUN/creatinine ratio. The patient's dehydration and hypotension indicate reduced renal perfusion, leading to increased urea reabsorption and a higher BUN/creatinine ratio. Obstructive uropathy typically presents with flank pain or urinary retention, which are absent here.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased protein catabolism can elevate urea production, but this is typically seen in severe trauma, burns, or sepsis. The patient's presentation, including dehydration and hypotension, suggests prerenal azotemia, where reduced renal perfusion enhances urea reabsorption, raising the BUN/creatinine ratio. There is no evidence of a hypercatabolic state.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. Three weeks ago, he underwent emergency cardiac catheterization for a myocardial infarction. His hospital stay was prolonged due to decreased kidney function. He reports that his symptoms have improved significantly and he is now urinating much more than before the procedure. His serum creatinine is 141 μmol/L (49–93) and blood urea nitrogen is 7.1 mmol/L (2.1–8.0). This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with AKI usually regain full glomerular filtration function approx. 2 weeks after the inciting event, while tubular reabsorption remains impaired, which results in increased urine production and consequent polyuria. The polyuric phase of AKI is characterized by the loss of several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including potassium, sodium, and magnesium.

Key learning point: The polyuric phase of acute kidney injury is marked by impaired tubular reabsorption, leading to excessive urinary loss of electrolytes such as potassium, sodium, and magnesium, and increasing the risk of hypokalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients in the polyuric phase of AKI are at risk for volume depletion, a state in which GFR and sodium delivery to the distal nephrons decreases, causing the release of renin. Therefore, this patient would actually have an increase in renin release.

C) INCORRECT:

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI. During this period, patients have difficulty excreting H+ ions and regenerating bicarbonate (a function of the tubular system), putting them at risk for metabolic acidosis, rather than alkalosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI and is actually at risk for hyponatremia, rather than hypernatremia. During this period, patients lose several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including sodium, into the urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI and is actually at risk for hypomagnesemia, rather than hypermagnesemia. During this period, patients lose several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including magnesium, into the urine.
questions.hint: This patient has most likely developed acute kidney injury (AKI) as a result of contrast-induced nephropathy (due to cardiac catheterization) and possibly renal ischemia due to myocardial infarction. The onset of polyuria three weeks after the development of AKI is consistent with the polyuric phase of AKI.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 20-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department with severe muscle soreness, nausea, and dark urine for 2 days. She is a member of the college track team and has been training intensively for an upcoming event. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. She has diffuse muscle tenderness over her arms, legs, and back. Laboratory studies show:


Creatine kinase (CK), blood

22,000 IU/L (30–190)


Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), blood

380 IU/L (100–205)


Blood, urine
3+


Protein, urine
1+


RBC, urine
Negative


Which one of the following complications is this patient at greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia, especially intravascular hemolytic anemia, may manifest with darkened urine as a result of the excess free hemoglobin circulating in the bloodstream. Free hemoglobin may accumulate during the breakdown and destruction of erythrocytes. This patient, however, most likely suffers from rhabdomyolysis, which does not cause hemolytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Acid-base disturbances are common in patients with rhabdomyolysis. Edema-associated muscle ischemia and excess muscle breakdown result in the production and/or release of organic acids, such as lactic acid or uric acid, which causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis rather than alkalosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome is a potentially limb-threatening surgical emergency that may cause or occur secondary to rhabdomyolysis. However, compartment syndrome secondary to rhabdomyolysis typically develops after fluid resuscitation, which this patient has not yet received. Another complication is more likely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Seizures can be caused by numerous factors, including metabolic and electrolyte abnormalities. While severe rhabdomyolysis manifests with hyperkalemia and lactic acidosis, seizures are not a common complication. Seizures, especially tonic-clonic ones, can cause (rather than result from) rhabdomyolysis secondary to excessive muscle contractions.

E) CORRECT:

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common complication of rhabdomyolysis and crush syndrome. The excessive muscle breakdown results in increased free myoglobin and subsequent myoglobinuria (darkened urine without detectable RBCs). Pigments of heme-containing proteins, e.g., myoglobin or hemoglobin can harm the kidney tubules (= pigment nephropathy), causing acute tubular necrosis and subsequent AKI. Volume depletion secondary to third-spacing of fluid into the injured muscles leads to decreased renal perfusion and may thus further impair kidney function.

Patients with rhabdomyolysis require careful resuscitation with IV fluids and close monitoring of their urine output and electrolytes. Hemodialysis may be indicated in cases of severe AKI. Patients should also be monitored for compartment syndrome, as overly rapid fluid resuscitation can lead to increasing edema of the injured muscle and its adjacent compartment, potentially threatening its perfusion.

Key learning point: Acute kidney injury is the most common and serious complication of rhabdomyolysis due to myoglobin-induced tubular damage.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with diffuse muscle tenderness, highly elevated creatine kinase, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase is suggestive of muscle injury. These features together with darkened urine in the absence of RBCs on urinalysis indicate rhabdomyolysis, most likely due to overexertion as a result of the intensive training.

questions.text: Ten days after being discharged from the hospital, a 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of reduced urine output. Physical examination is normal. His serum creatinine concentration is 256 μmol/L (49–93). Urinalysis reveals brownish granular casts and 2+ proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows patchy necrosis of the proximal convoluted tubule with sloughing of tubular cells into the lumen and preservation of tubular basement membranes. Which one of the following drugs administered during his hospitalization is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Aminoglycoside antibiotics such as gentamicin are one of the most common causes of toxic ATN, which is characterized by damage and possible consequent necrosis of the proximal convoluted tubules, as seen on this patient's biopsy findings. ATN manifests with oliguria, uremia, and muddy brown granular casts within the first two weeks of a kidney injury. Treatment includes discontinuation of nephrotoxic agents, supportive care, and dialysis if necessary.

Key learning point: Aminoglycosides such as gentamicin are a common cause of acute tubular necrosis, presenting with muddy brown granular casts and proximal tubular cell injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral agent used to treat herpes simplex and varicella zoster infections. Acyclovir can cause crystal-induced acute kidney injury, which can manifest with elevated creatinine and proteinuria. However, in the case of crystal-induced nephropathy, crystals would be visible on urine microscopy rather than granular casts. Acyclovir is therefore an unlikely cause of this patient's renal failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is a type of NSAID typically used in the management of pain, fever, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease prophylaxis. NSAIDs can cause allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN). AIN can manifest with oliguria and elevated creatinine, which are seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features of AIN, e.g., fever, rash, and eosinophiluria. Additionally, renal biopsy in AIN shows interstitial edema with mononuclear infiltrate. This is inconsistent with this patient's biopsy findings, making aspirin an unlikely cause of his renal failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) commonly used to treat peptic ulcer disease and dyspepsia. A rare side effect of PPI agents is allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN). AIN can manifest with oliguria and elevated creatinine, as in this patient. However, this patient lacks other classic features of AIN, e.g., fever, rash, and eosinophiluria. Additionally, renal biopsy in AIN shows interstitial edema with mononuclear infiltrate. This is inconsistent with this patient's biopsy findings, making omeprazole an unlikely cause of his renal failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor used in the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. In cases of renal hypoperfusion, such as intravascular volume depletion and bilateral renal artery stenosis, ACE inhibitors can cause decreased GFR, elevated creatinine, and oliguria, as in this patient. However, ACE inhibitors would not result in ATN or significant findings on renal biopsy, making captopril an unlikely cause of this patient's renal failure.
questions.hint: Oliguria, elevated serum creatinine, granular muddy brown casts, proteinuria, and patchy necrosis of the proximal tubule indicate acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with weakness and decreased urine output for two days. She reports undergoing a contrast-enhanced CT pulmonary angiogram 4 days ago for evaluation of acute chest pain, which ruled out pulmonary embolism. The day after discharge from the hospital she developed mild gastroenteritis, that resolved after 24 hours. Her medical history includes hypertension, treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are BP, 102/60 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 16; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows mild dry mucous membranes and no flank tenderness. Bedside bladder ultrasound reveals a partially full bladder with a postvoid residual of 110 mL. Laboratory results show sodium 138 mEq/L; potassium 5.6 mEq/L; bicarbonate 18 mEq/L; BUN 52 mg/dL; creatinine 3.2 mg/dL (previously 1.0 mg/dL); hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL; platelets 225 ×10³/µL; peripheral smear without schistocytes. Urinalysis demonstrates muddy brown granular casts and no evidence of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer a 2-L bolus of isotonic saline
Decompress the bladder via urethral catheterization
Discontinue lisinopril and initiate cautious fluid management
Begin high-dose corticosteroids for suspected acute interstitial nephritis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although mild dehydration may contribute, the presence of muddy brown casts indicates acute tubular necrosis (ATN) rather than prerenal azotemia. Aggressive fluid administration can worsen renal injury and electrolyte disturbances.

B) INCORRECT:

Postrenal acute kidney injury typically presents with significant bladder distention and postvoid residuals >200 mL. The findings are consistent with intrinsic renal injury rather than obstruction.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — The marked rise in creatinine within days of a contrast-enhanced CT pulmonary angiogram, in combination with granular casts, suggests a contrast-induced acute tubular necrosis. Management is supportive: discontinue nephrotoxic medications, maintain gentle hydration, monitor potassium and acid–base status, and arrange nephrology consultation if renal function fails to improve.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are an appropriate treatment for drug-induced interstitial nephritis; however, drug-induced interstitial nephritis presents with fever, rash, eosinophilia, and sterile pyuria, not muddy brown casts.

E) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics may transiently increase urine volume but do not improve renal recovery in acute tubular necrosis. They are used only to manage symptomatic volume overload once euvolemia has been achieved. Additionally, loop diuretics would be inappropriate in a patient who is hypotensive secondary to dehydration.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought from her nursing home due to lethargy and confusion for the past day. For the last three days, she has had multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and has been eating and drinking poorly. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide and ibuprofen as needed for knee pain. On physical examination, she is tachycardic at 110/min and her blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. She has dry oral mucosa and decreased skin turgor. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine of 2.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL) and a blood urea nitrogen of 65 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is an allergic or inflammatory condition of the kidney interstitium. While ibuprofen is a potential cause of drug-induced AIN, this diagnosis is less likely. The classic presentation of AIN includes fever, rash, and eosinophilia, none of which are described. This patient's clinical picture is overwhelmingly dominated by signs of volume depletion.

B) INCORRECT:

Postrenal obstruction causes acute kidney injury by blocking urine outflow. This diagnosis is unlikely as this patient's history and physical examination lack any findings suggestive of obstruction, such as anuria, suprapubic pain, a palpable bladder, or a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia or nephrolithiasis. The clinical evidence strongly points to a perfusion issue.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is an intrinsic kidney injury caused by ischemia or nephrotoxins. In ATN, damaged renal tubules are unable to reabsorb urea efficiently, typically resulting in a BUN:creatinine ratio of less than 15:1. The current findings are more consistent with a different pathology.

D) CORRECT:

Prerenal azotemia, or prerenal acute kidney injury, is caused by decreased renal perfusion. This patient has multiple risk factors for hypovolemia, including diarrhea, poor oral intake, and hydrochlorothiazide use. Her physical examination findings of tachycardia, hypotension, and dry mucous membranes confirm this volume-depleted state. Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, further impairs renal perfusion by constricting the afferent arterioles. The classic laboratory finding is a BUN:creatinine ratio > 20:1 (65:2.8 ≈ 23:1), which occurs because the kidneys avidly reabsorb sodium, water, and urea in response to low flow, raising BUN disproportionately to creatinine. Treatment is focused on restoring renal perfusion with intravenous fluids.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiorenal syndrome refers to acute kidney injury resulting from severe cardiac dysfunction, such as decompensated heart failure. Although this patient is an older adult with a history of hypertension, there are no signs of heart failure, like jugular venous distention, pulmonary rales, or peripheral edema. The hypotension and signs of dehydration point to hypovolemia rather than poor cardiac output as the cause of renal impairment.
questions.hint: This patient's signs of dehydration and the blood urea nitrogen (BUN) to creatinine ratio are key to identifying the cause of her kidney injury.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man was admitted 5 days ago for complicated pyelonephritis. Today, his urine output has decreased significantly. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, ceftriaxone, and gentamicin. Latest laboratory studies show a serum creatinine of 3.9 mg/dL, up from 1.1 mg/dL on admission, with a blood urea nitrogen of 75 mg/dL. A urinalysis is performed and shows muddy brown granular casts and renal tubular epithelial cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's renal failure?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Gentamicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is a well-known cause of nephrotoxic ATN. It accumulates in the proximal tubular cells, causing direct cellular injury and necrosis. The onset of aminoglycoside-induced nephrotoxicity is typically delayed, occurring 5–10 days after initiation of therapy, which fits this patient's clinical timeline. The diagnosis is strongly supported by the acute rise in creatinine, oliguria, and the pathognomonic urinalysis finding of muddy brown granular casts and renal tubular epithelial cells. His age and underlying diabetes are also risk factors for this complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, can cause acute kidney injury, particularly with volume depletion or bilateral renal artery stenosis. However, the mechanism is hemodynamic (prerenal) and is caused by efferent arteriole vasodilation, which reduces glomerular filtration pressure. This would typically result in a bland urinalysis without the cellular casts seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

While severe pyelonephritis can lead to sepsis and subsequent ischemic ATN, the urinalysis findings would primarily show WBC casts, pyuria, and bacteriuria. The presence of muddy brown casts suggests direct tubular injury from another cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin is not directly nephrotoxic and does not cause ATN. It is cleared by the kidneys, and its use is contraindicated in patients with significant renal impairment because accumulation increases the risk of life-threatening lactic acidosis. Therefore, this patient's acute kidney injury is a reason to discontinue metformin, but metformin is not the cause of the injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy is a chronic kidney disease that develops over many years. It would not cause an acute rise in creatinine from a normal baseline to 3.9 mg/dL over 5 days. This patient's presentation is clearly an acute process, although his underlying diabetes may make him more susceptible to acute kidney injury.
questions.hint: The presence of muddy brown granular casts on urinalysis is a pathognomonic finding that suggests acute tubular necrosis (ATN), a form of intrinsic acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A 71-year-old hospitalized man develops abnormal laboratory studies 4 days after starting treatment for exacerbation of congestive heart failure. He also has a history of osteoarthritis and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He recently completed a course of amikacin for bacterial prostatitis. Before hospitalization, his medications included simvastatin and ibuprofen. Blood pressure is 111/76 mm Hg. Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL (previously normal) and a BUN of 48 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows a urine osmolality of 600 mOsm/kg and urine sodium of 10 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's renal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has likely developed AKI as a result of volume depletion induced by loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide), which is an important part of pharmacotherapy for decompensated congestive heart failure (CHF). This patient's baseline renal blood flow is most likely already reduced as a result of systolic dysfunction. Excess diuresis (e.g., due to loop diuretics) and consequent volume depletion further increases the degree of renal hypoperfusion, which stimulates the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Aldosterone causes sodium and water retention in an attempt to maintain the glomerular filtration rate and systemic blood pressure, which, in turn, increases urea reabsorption (BUN:creatinine ratio ≥ 20:1). The increase in sodium and water retention causes an increase in urine osmolality. Patients with CHF being treated with loop diuretics should have renal laboratory values monitored because of the potential adverse effects on the kidney.

B) INCORRECT:

UTIs with renal involvement can cause inflammation and necrosis of the renal papillae, resulting in intrarenal (intrinsic) AKI. In intrinsic AKI, the function of tubular cells is impaired, leading to elevated creatinine levels, but a decreased (not increased) BUN:creatinine ratio (≤ 15:1) because of decreased urea reabsorption. In addition, sodium reabsorption and the ability to concentrate the urine would be impaired, causing a urine sodium concentration > 30 mEq/L and urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/kg, respectively, which is inconsistent with this patient's urinalysis. Additionally, there are no signs of infection (e.g., dysuria, frequency, urgency).

C) INCORRECT:

Benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction and postrenal AKI in elderly men. Although patients present with elevated creatinine, the function of the tubular system remains intact so the kidney's ability to concentrate urine and reabsorb sodium and urea are normal. Serum studies would show urine osmolality 300–500 mOsm/kg, urine sodium concentration 10-30 mEq/L), and a normal BUN:creatinine ratio (10–20:1). Although this patient has BPH, his laboratory values are inconsistent with postrenal AKI.

D) INCORRECT:

Glomerulonephritis can cause intrinsic AKI. Although patients present with elevated creatinine levels, the direct injury to the glomeruli results in proteinuria and/or hematuria, as well as impaired sodium reabsorption (urine sodium concentration > 30 mEq/L), hypotonic urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/kg, and impaired urea reabsorption BUN:creatinine ratio (≤ 15:1), none of which are consistent with the findings in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal tubular obstruction can be caused by multiple myeloma (MM) and can result in intrinsic AKI due to light chains obstructing the renal tubule and direct toxicity to renal tissue. Renal tubular dysfunction causes elevated creatinine levels, but a decreased BUN:creatinine ratio (≤ 15:1) because of decreased urea reabsorption. In addition, sodium reabsorption and the ability to concentrate the urine would be impaired, causing a urine sodium concentration > 30 mEq/L and urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/kg, respectively, which is inconsistent with this patient's urinalysis. This patient lacks typical findings of MM, such as proteinuria, bone pain, and anemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Amikacin and other aminoglycosides are nephrotoxic and can result in intrinsic AKI due to direct damage to the tubular system. Renal tubular dysfunction causes elevated creatinine levels, but a decreased BUN:creatinine ratio (≤ 15:1) because of decreased urea reabsorption. In addition, sodium reabsorption and the ability to concentrate the urine would be impaired, causing a urine sodium concentration > 30 mEq/L and urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/kg, respectively, which is inconsistent with this patient's urinalysis. Although this patient was treated with amikacin, his laboratory findings are inconsistent with intrinsic AKI.
